docs.lead_paragraph: The $787 billion economic stimulus bill approved by Congress will provide $1.1 billion for federal researchers to compare a variety of medical treatments that are all prescribed for the same conditions. The goal is to find which drugs, devices and surgery really work, and to stop using costly ineffective methods.

headline.main: Comparing the Costs of Medical Treatments

docs.abstract: Most consumers believe doctors -- not the government or insurance companies -- ultimately should make decisions about what treatments are best for their patients.
docs.snippet: Most consumers believe doctors -- not the government or insurance companies -- ultimately should make decisions about what treatments are best for their patients.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama’s budget will call for stricter limits on itemized deductions, introducing a politically volatile edge to the debate over his domestic priorities.

docs.lead_paragraph: When Sheryl Crow said that people should use only one sheet of toilet paper, she was lampooned by everyone from Rush Limbaugh to Jon Stewart.

headline.main: Toilet Paper and Other Moral Choices

docs.abstract: Apart from the choice of toilet paper, what are the simplest changes that Americans can adopt that would make an environmental difference?
docs.snippet: Apart from the choice of toilet paper, what are the simplest changes that Americans can adopt that would make an environmental difference?

docs.lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama said in his speech to Congress that the nation must address "the crushing cost of health care," with premiums having grown four times faster than wages in the past eight years and one million more Americans having lost health insurance each of those years. Reform won't be easy, he said, but it cannot wait another year.
docs.abstract: President Barack Obama said health care reform cannot wait another year. Some experts offer their ideas for how to get reform off the ground.
docs.snippet: President Barack Obama said health care reform cannot wait another year. Some experts offer their ideas for how to get reform off the ground.

docs.lead_paragraph: Over the past two decades, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has been quietly buying up space in the building next door to his home, knocking down walls and combining two entire floors along the way. In addition to his building at 17 East 79th Street, he now owns four of the six apartments at 19 East 79th, a white 1880 neo-Grec co-op town house.

headline.main: He's Also the Mayor of His Block

docs.abstract: Also in Morning Buzz: special City Council election results; the governor's slipping ratings; and other headlines from local papers.
docs.snippet: Also in Morning Buzz: special City Council election results; the governor's slipping ratings; and other headlines from local papers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Big banks keep insisting that they have all the capital they need - a claim that might strike many people as absurd when the government is spending billions of taxpayer dollars to prop up the financial industry.

headline.main: Stress Test for Banks Exposes Rift on Wall St.

docs.abstract: Big banks keep insisting that they have all the capital they need - a claim that might strike many people as absurd when the government is spending billions of taxpayer dollars to prop up the financial industry. So here is a surprise: By some common measures, the banks do have enough capital. The problem is, [...]
